questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with flank pain and dysuria. The pain was temporarily relieved by intravenous analgesics administered at a nearby primary healthcare center. She is diagnosed with ureteric colic secondary to ureteric calculi. What is the most appropriate diagnostic modality in this case?
questions.explanation:
Investigations for renal stones:

Urinalysis
  • This is often the initial investigation performed. It can reveal the presence of blood (hematuria), white blood cells (pyuria), and crystals in the urine, all suggestive of a possible stone.
  • The pH of the urine can also give clues about the type of stone.

Kidney, Ureter, and Bladder (KUB) X-ray

It can detect some types of stones, particularly calcium-containing stones, which appear opaque on X-rays.

Ultrasound

(Option C ruled out)

It's particularly useful for detecting hydronephrosis (swelling of the kidney due to urine blockage) caused by stones and can be helpful during pregnancy when minimising radiation exposure is important.

Intravenous urogram (IVU)
  • It involves injecting a contrast dye into a vein.
  • The dye travels through the bloodstream to the kidneys, where it is filtered and excreted in the urine.
  • X-rays are taken as the dye passes through the urinary tract, outlining the kidneys, ureters, and bladder.
  • This test can reveal blockages in the urinary tract caused by stones.

questions.text: Identify the structure on prostate biopsy:

A newborn male presents with urinary retention, lethargy and a distended bladder. Antenatal ultrasound showed a "keyhole sign" with a thickened bladder wall. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Posterior urethral valves

Definition

Urinary tract obstruction in male infants from membranous folds in the posterior urethra.

Complications

Chronic kidney disease, pulmonary hypoplasia from oligohydramnios.

Classification

Type I: Posterior urethral folds

Type II: Membranes at bladder neck

Type III: Round membrane at verumontanum

Etiology

Congenital, unclear embryological origin.

Pathophysiology

Increased bladder pressure → hypertrophy, vesicoureteric reflux, renal damage

Diagnostic Tools

Ultrasound, VCUG (voiding cystourethrogram) and Renal scintigraphy.

Antenatal Diagnosis

Ultrasound: Dilated bladder ("keyhole sign"), thickened walls.

Postnatal Symptoms

Urinary retention, infections, lethargy, respiratory distress.

Management
  • Antenatal: Vesicostomy, fetal valve ablation
  • Postnatal: Stabilization, cystoscopic ablation

Prognosis

Depends on severity; long-term care needed for CKD, bladder dysfunction, recurrent UTIs.

Posterior Urethral Valve

Congenital anomaly

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a bulky scrotal swelling. On evaluation, malignancy is suspected, and an orchidectomy is performed. The gross section of the testicular mass is shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Details

Tumor Type

Seminoma, the most common pure testicular germ cell tumour in men aged 25-45

Origin

Germinal epithelium of the seminiferous tubules

Clinical Features

Painless, firm swelling or mass in the testicle, typically unilateral. Accounts for 50% of all testicular germ cell tumors. 10% have secondary hydrocele, 5% have gynecomastia

Diagnostic Markers

AFP: Normal

hCG: Normal or mildly elevated

LDH: Elevated

Investigation

Ultrasound: Homogeneous, hypoechoic mass

Histology: Sheets of oval cells with clear cytoplasm, large nuclei with prominent acidophilic nucleoli

FNAC: Contraindicated due to risk of tumor cell seeding and lymph node metastasis

Treatment

Primary: High Inguinal Radical Orchidectomy

Adjuvant: Radiation therapy or chemotherapy for positive lymph nodes

Tumor marker

Types of Tumor

AFP (Alpha-fetoprotein)
  • Yolk sac tumor
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Teratoma

HCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin)
  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Mixed Germ Cell Tumor

LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase)
  • Seminoma

PLAP (Placenta Like Alkaline Phosphatase)
  • Seminoma

GGT (Gamma Glutamyl Transpeptidase)
  • Seminoma

questions.text: An adult male presents to the outpatient department with a painful scrotal swelling accompanied by fever. The swelling is associated with the tunica vaginalis and is characterized by fluid accumulation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aetiology
  • Defective absorption of fluid by tunica vaginalis due to endothelial wall damage by low-grade infection
  • Excessive production of fluid (secondary hydrocele)
  • Interference with drainage of fluid by lymphatic vessels of the cord
  • Communication with the peritoneal cavity

Primary Vaginal Hydrocele
  • Common in middle-aged men, prevalent in tropical countries
  • Testis is usually large and non-palpable
  • Fluctuant
  • Can get above the swelling
  • Initially transilluminant, but becomes non-transilluminant if long-standing

Infantile Hydrocele
  • Tunica and processus vaginalis distended up to the internal ring
  • No connection with the peritoneal cavity

Congenital Hydrocele
  • Processus vaginalis communicates with the peritoneal cavity
  • Fluid disappears when lying down and recollects when standing

Encysted Hydrocele of the Cord
  • Fluid collection in a portion of the patent funicular process of tunica vaginalis
  • Fluctuant and transilluminant
  • Located in the inguinal/inguinoscrotal/scrotal part

Secondary Vaginal Hydrocele
  • Causes: Infection (filariasis, tuberculosis), injury (trauma, post herniorrhaphy), tumor (malignancy)
  • Usually small, lax, and testis is palpable except in cases of filariasis where it can be very large

Surgical Procedure
  • Lord's plication - small, thin hydrocele with clear fluid
  • Jaboulay's operation - partial sac removal and eversion

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with gynecomastia. Ultrasound reveals a 1 cm solid mass within the body of the testis. Serum testosterone is 600 ng/dL, and estradiol is 35 pg/mL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Leydig cell tumour

Sertoli cell tumour

Hormonal involvement

It often involves androgens, oestrogens, and corticosteroids.

Hormonally silent.

Conditions associated with
  • Klinefelter syndrome.
  • Cryptorchidism.
  • Renal cell carcinoma.
  • Carney complex.
  • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis.

Malignancy

10% (in adults)

10%

Gross
  • Circumscribed nodules, usually < 5 cm in diameter.
  • They have a distinctive golden brown, homogeneous appearance on cut surfaces.

Firm, small nodules with a homogeneous

grey-white to yellow cut surface.

 

Histology
  • The tumour cells resemble their normal counterparts.
  • They are large in size and have round or polygonal cell outlines, abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm, and a round central nucleus.
  • The cytoplasm frequently contains lipid droplets, vacuoles, or lipofuscin pigment and, most characteristically, rod-shaped Reinke crystalloids (25% of the tumours).
  • The tumour cells are arranged in distinctive trabeculae that tend to form cord-like structures and tubules.

 

Image

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with abdominal pain. A CECT (Contrast Enhanced CT) abdomen was done. What is the likely source of pain?
questions.explanation:
Treatment of RCC: RCCs are radio and chemo-resistant.

Surgical Management:

Partial Nephrectomy (Option A): Involves removing only the tumour while preserving the remainder of the kidney.

Indications:

  • T1 Disease(<7cm)
  • Restricted to poles
  • RCC in solitary functioning kidney
  • Radical Nephrectomy: Involves removal of the kidney with Gerota’s fascia, para-aortic nodes, and ureter up to the pelvic brim.
  • Indications: Larger tumours or when partial nephrectomy is not feasible

Ablative Techniques

Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA) and Cryoablation Involve destroying the tumor using extreme temperatures.

Indications:

  • Patients who are not surgical candidates
  • Patients with small tumours (T1a lesions) (usually <4 cm).

Systemic Therapy

(For advanced/ metastatic disease)

Targeted Therapy

  • Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., sunitinib, pazopanib)
  • mTOR inhibitors (e.g., everolimus)

Immunotherapy: Immune checkpoint inhibitors (e.g., nivolumab)

questions.text: Identify the condition in the image:
questions.explanation:
Feature

Anterior Urethral Injury

Posterior Urethral Injury

Location
  • Bulbar urethra (most common)
  • Penile urethra
  • Membranous urethra (bulbomembranous junction most common)
  • Prostatic urethra

 

Common Causes
  • Straddle injuries
  • Direct trauma
  • Iatrogenic injuries (catheterization, cystoscopy)
  • Penetrating trauma (stab/gunshot wounds)
  • Pelvic fractures (often due to motor vehicle accidents)
  • Blunt trauma

Clinical Features
  • Hematuria (blood in urine)
  • Penile/perineal bruising (butterfly-shaped hematoma)
  • Perineal pain
  • Urinary retention or difficulty voiding
  • Possible swelling of the penis or scrotum due to hematoma
  • Blood at the meatus
  • Inability to void
  • High-riding prostate on rectal exam
  • Perineal or suprapubic pain
  • Pelvic hematoma associated with pelvic fractures
  • Possible concomitant bladder injury

Investigations
  • Retrograde Urethrography (RGU): Gold standard, shows the extent and location of the injury.
  • Voiding Cystourethrography (VCUG): Used to assess urethral patency post-repair
  • Ultrasound: Can detect hematoma or associated injuries
  • Retrograde Urethrography (RGU): Gold standard for initial assessment
  • CT Urethrography: Useful in evaluating complex injuries
  • Pelvic CT Scan: Important for associated pelvic fractures
  • Cystoscopy: Sometimes performed for further evaluation
  • If injury at Prostatomembranous junction - High lying prostate → On IVP- Pie in-sky appearance

questions.text: A patient develops a severe infection and necrosis in the scrotal region after 5 days of catheterization. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Fournier's Gangrene

Definition
  • Necrotizing infection of the soft tissues in the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region, akin to necrotizing fasciitis.

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms: Intense pain in the genitalia, progressing through

five phases:

    • Prodromal Phase: Fever and lethargy.
    • Early Pain Phase: Intense pain, possible edema, pruritus.
    • Progressive Phase: Increased pain, and erythema.
    • Crepitation Phase: Dusky skin with subcutaneous crepitation.
    • Gangrene Phase: Gangrene with purulent discharge.
  • Pain may decrease as gangrene progresses.
  • Severity ranges from localized tenderness to septic shock.

Risk Factors
  • Peripheral vascular disease, diabetes mellitus, malnutrition, alcoholism, immunocompromised states.

Diagnosis
  • Clinical presentation supported by imaging or lab findings.

Management
  • Initial Treatment:
    • Fluid resuscitation.
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics.
    • Surgical debridement of necrotic tissue.
  • Additional Measures:
    • Urinary and faecal diversion to prevent wound contamination.
    • Intensive monitoring for sepsis.
    • Wound review and vacuum-assisted dressing.
    • Skin grafting post-infection control.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with a painless mass in the abdomen. Upon examination, a large mobile abdominal mass is noted, and it does not cross the midline. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Wilm’s tu

1. Nephroblastoma (Wilms tumor):

  • It is a rare kidney cancer that mainly affects children.
  • Hematogenous spread.
  • Early metastasis to lung.
  • Treatment by chemotherapy followed by surgery.
  • It most often affects children ages 3 to 4.
  • Nephroblastoma is a malignant or cancerous tumor that originates in the kidney cells.
  • Symptoms of Nephroblastoma:
    • A mass in the stomach area that can be felt.
    • Swelling in the stomach area.
    • Pain in the stomach area.
    • Fever.
    • Blood in the urine.
    • Low red blood cell level, also known as anemia.
    • High blood pressure.

2. Stages of Nephroblastoma:

  • Stage I indicates the tumor was completely contained within the kidney without any breaks or spillage outside the renal capsule and no vascular invasion. This stage accounts for 40% to 45% of all Wilms tumors.
  • Stage II would be a tumor that has grown outside the kidney to some degree, such as into surrounding fatty tissue. Usually, the tumor would be completely removable by surgery, and regional lymph nodes are negative. About 20% of all Wilms tumors are at this stage.
  • Stage III comprises about 20% to 25% of all Wilms tumors and indicates a tumor which could not be completely removed surgically such as the following:
    • Cancer has spread to the regional lymph nodes but not to more distant nodes, such as in the chest
    • Cancer has grown into nearby vital structures so it could not be surgically removed completely
    • Deposits of the tumor (tumor implants) are found in the peritoneum, or there are positive surgical margins
    • Cancer cells were accidentally “spilled” into the abdominal cavity during surgery
    • The tumor was removed in separate pieces surgically; such as one piece from the kidney and another from the adrenal gland
    • A renal biopsy of the tumor was done before it was surgically removed.
  • Stage IV tumors are those that have spread through the vascular system to distant organs such as the lungs, liver, brain, or bones, or to distant lymph nodes. These account for about 10% of all Wilms tumors.
  • Stage V are those cases where both kidneys are involved with tumor at the time of initial diagnosis. About 5% of all Wilms tumors are at this stage. Individual staging of each renal unit is needed as well.

3. Treatments of Nephroblastoma:

  • Wilms tumor is chemosensitive.
  • Treatment of Wilms tumor is usually nephrectomy followed by systemic chemotherapy, but some protocols initiate chemotherapy first and do the nephrectomy later.
  • The opposite kidney may be explored to ensure that cancer has not spread, although this is unnecessary for low-stage tumors with favorable histology if imaging is negative.
  • Lymph nodes around the aorta are sampled for staging and to improve survival.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with complaints of dysuria and intermittent back pain. On examination, there are no palpable abdominal masses or tenderness. An X-ray image of the abdomen is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
System

Manifestations

Reason

Renal system (stones)

  • Hypercalciuria
  • Nephrocalcinosis
  • Nephrolithiasis
  • Polydipsia, polyuria, nocturia
  • Excretion of excess serum calcium
  • Calcium deposition in renal parenchyma
  • Precipitation of calcium with phosphate or oxalate
  • Inhibition of ADH due to ↑ serum calcium.

Skeletal system
  • Osteoporosis
  • Subperiosteal resorption(radial aspect)
  • Tufting of distal phalanx
  • Brown tumour/ osteitis fibrosa cystica
  • Salt and pepper skull
  • Chondrocalcinosis
  • Pseudo gout
  • Joint pain
  • Calcium resorption
  • Deposition of hemosiderin in the lesion.

Abdomen

(abdominal groans)
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Constipation
  • Peptic ulcer disease: abdominal groans
  • Inhibitory effect of hypercalcemia on gastrointestinal (GI) smooth muscle contraction.
  • Spasm of sphincters
  • Increased gastrin

CNS

(psychiatric moans)
  • Confusion
  • Anxiety
  • Depression
  • Psychosis: psychic moans
  • Some mild memory loss
  • Depression of the nervous system

Muscular system
  • Weakness
  • Fatigue overtones
  • Decreased muscle activity.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with verrucous carcinoma around the glans of the penis. Examination reveals that the inguinal lymph nodes are not enlarged. What is the appropriate management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Cancer Type/Stage

Management

Localized Tumor - Glans Only

Partial penectomy

Distal Penile Involvement

Partial penectomy with 2cm margin

Proximal Penile Involvement

/Anaplastic Tumors

Total penectomy with perineal urethrostomy

Carcinoma in situ, T1 Lesions, Well-Differentiated Tumors in Young

Circumcision followed by curative radiotherapy

Inguinal Lymph Node Involvement

Bilateral ilioinguinal lymph node dissection

Advanced Disease - T2 or Poorly Differentiated Tumors

Prophylactic inguinal nodal dissection

Carcinoma in situ

Topical treatments (5-FU cream, imiquimod), Mohs surgery, laser therapy, or limited excision

Chemotherapy

Combination chemotherapy (5-FU, methotrexate, bleomycin, cisplatin, vincristine)

Stage

Description

TX

Primary tumours cannot be assessed

T0

No evidence of a primary tumour

Tis

Carcinoma in situ (Penile intraepithelial neoplasia, PeIN)

Ta

Noninvasive localised squamous cell carcinoma

T1

Tumor invades lamina propria, dermis, or connective tissue with/without lymphovascular or perineural invasion

  • T1a: without invasion/high grade
  • T1b: with invasion/high grade

T2

Tumor invades corpus spongiosum with or without urethral invasion

T3

Tumor invades corpora cavernosa with or without urethral invasion

T4

Tumor invades adjacent structures (e.g., prostate, scrotum, pubic bone)

cNX

Regional nodes cannot be assessed

cN0

No palpable or visible enlarged inguinal nodes

cN1

Palpable mobile unilateral inguinal lymph node

cN2

Palpable mobile unilateral ≥2 inguinal lymph nodes

cN3

Palpable fixed inguinal nodal mass or pelvic lymphadenopathy (unilateral or bilateral)

cM0

No distant metastases

cM1

Distant metastases

pM1

Distant metastasis microscopically confirmed

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents with hematuria and a neovascular mass in the left kidney on a CT scan, as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Arise from
  • Perivascular epithelioid cells

Types
  • Sporadic AMLs: Present in the 4th-6th decades, typically small, solitary, and slow-growing.
  • TSC-associated AMLs: Present earlier (3rd-4th decades), larger, multiple, bilateral, and tend to grow.

Symptoms

  • Abdominal or flank pain, hematuria, hypertension, anemia.
  • Impaired kidney function, usually due to hemorrhage (severe complication).
  • Wunderlich syndrome: Nontraumatic kidney hemorrhage.

Risk Factors for AML Complications
  • Pregnancy: Increased risk of hemorrhage
  • TSC-associated AMLs: Higher risk of CKD and ESKD
  • Epithelioid AMLs: Potential for malignant transformation, metastasis, and local recurrence.

 

Risk factors for hemorrhage:

  • AML size (>6 cm)
  • Increased vascularity
  • Large intralesional aneurysms (>5 mm)
  • Exophytic growth pattern.

Histology

Circular blood vessels, muscles, and fat; perivascular epithelioid cells with dense eosinophilic cytoplasm and mitotic figures.

Diagnosis
  • CT: (Investigation of choice) Presence of intralesional fat and neovascular mass.
  • USG: Appears as hyperechoic
  • Immunocytochemical analysis: Differentiates AML from RCC, using markers like HMB-45 and melan-A.

Treatment
  • Observation (tumors <4 cm)
  • Nephron-Sparing Surgery(Partial nephrectomy) (larger tumors or those with a high risk of bleeding)
  • Angioembolization (acute hemorrhage).
  • Medications (mTOR inhibitors like everolimus and sirolimus).

questions.text: Which lymph node is most commonly involved in prostate cancer?
questions.explanation:
• Most common malignant tumor in men over the age of 65 years.
  • Most common among Afro-American

Risk factor

  • Advanced age
  • High-fat diet

Protective factors

(Mnemonic: LESA)

  • Lycopene
  • Vitamin E
  • Selenium
  • Vitamin A

Pathology

  • Most common site- peripheral zone (75%) > transitional zone (15%) > central zone (10%)
  • Most common histological type is adenocarcinoma
  • Most common genetic alteration seen in CA prostate- hypermethylation of GSTP1 (Glutathione transferase promoter region 1) located on chromosome 11.
  • 70-80% of the cases.
  • Microscopy: small, crowded, absent basal layer, lack of branching

Clinical features
  • Commonly asymptomatic.
  • Bladder outlet obstruction.
  • Haematuria
  • Pelvic pain, back pain, arthritic pain in sacroiliac joint-features of secondaries
  • On per rectal examination: hard, nodular, irregular often with loss of median groove.

Routes of spread
  • Most common route of spread- haematogenous (skeletal metastases: pelvic bones and the lower lumbar vertebrae)
  • Lymphatic: Internal iliac, external iliac lymph nodes, retroperitoneal lymph nodes, mediastinal nodes and occasionally the supraclavicular nodes.

Investigations

  • DRE (Digital Rectal Exam): Physical examination; detects nodules but limited in early-stage
  • PSA (prostate-specific antigen) Test: Measures PSA levels; elevated levels suggest cancer
  • TRUS (Transrectal Ultrasound): Imaging with rectal probe; detects abnormalities
  • mpMRI (Multiparametric MRI): Advanced imaging; superior for staging and capsular spread
  • Prostate Biopsy: Gold standard for diagnosis; tissue sampling for cancer cells

Management

  • Active Surveillance: For low-risk cases; regular monitoring
  • Radical Prostatectomy: Surgery for localized cancer; potentially curative
  • Radiation Therapy: High-energy rays; external or brachytherapy
  • Hormone Therapy: Reduces/block testosterone; for advanced/metastatic cases
  • Chemotherapy: Systemic drug treatment; for advanced/metastatic cases

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the following image?

options.label: A
options.text: Staphylococcus aureus is the causative organism

questions.correct_answer: A. Staphylococcus aureus is the causative organism
questions.explanation:
Fournier's Gangrene

Definition

Necrotizing infection of the soft tissues in the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region, akin to necrotizing fasciitis.

Causative Organisms

Mixed infection of aerobic and anaerobic bacteria in a fulminating inflammation of the subcutaneous tissues. (Option A)

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms: Intense pain in the genitalia, progressing through five phases:
    • Prodromal Phase: Fever and lethargy.
    • Early Pain Phase: Intense pain, possible edema, pruritus.
    • Progressive Phase: Increased pain, erythema.
    • Crepitation Phase: Dusky skin with subcutaneous crepitation.
    • Gangrene Phase: Gangrene with purulent discharge.
  • Pain may decrease as gangrene progresses.
  • Severity ranges from localized tenderness to septic shock.

Risk Factors
  • Peripheral vascular disease
  • Diabetes mellitus (Option B ruled out)
  • Malnutrition
  • Alcoholism
  • Immunocompromised states.

Diagnosis
  • Clinical presentation supported by imaging or lab findings.

Management

Initial Treatment:

  • Fluid resuscitation.
  • Broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • Surgical debridement of necrotic tissue.

Additional Measures:

  • Daily rounds (high rates mortality and morbidity) (Option C ruled out)
  • Urinary and fecal diversion to prevent wound contamination.
  • Intensive monitoring for sepsis.
  • Wound review and vacuum-assisted dressing.
  • Skin grafting post-infection control.

questions.text: What type of hernia is a funicular hernia? Direct inguinal hernia
questions.explanation:
Feature

Indirect Inguinal Hernia

Direct Inguinal Hernia

(Option A ruled out)

Common in

Young adults

Elderly

Course

It enters through the deep inguinal ring, traverses the inguinal canal, and exits via the superficial inguinal ring.

Protrudes directly through Hesselbach's triangle

Relation to Spermatic Cord

Anterolateral to the spermatic cord

Posterior to the spermatic cord

Location of Neck of Sac

Above and medial to the pubic tubercle.

Lies within the Hesselbach's triangle.

Relation to Inferior Epigastric vessels

Lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels.

Medial to the inferior epigastric vessels.

Relation to Scrotum

Descends into the scrotum

Does not Descend

Types
  • Bubonocele: Confined to inguinal canal
  • Funicular: Processus vaginalis closed above epididymis, hernia content distinct from testis (Option B)
  • Complete/Scrotal: Testis in the lower part of the hernia

 

 

—

Type I

Indirect inguinal hernia

  • Normal internal inguinal ring
    • e.g., pediatric hernia

Type II

Indirect inguinal hernia

  • Dilated internal inguinal ring
  • Posterior inguinal wall intact

Type III

A: Direct inguinal hernia

B: Indirect inguinal hernia

  • Internal inguinal ring dilated
  • Encroaching medially or destroying the transversalis fascia of the Hesselbach triangle (e.g. scrotal sliding or pantaloon hernia)

C: Femoral hernia

Type IV (Recurrent Hernia)

A: Direct

B: Indirect

C: Femoral

D: Combined

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient came to the outpatient department with complaints of hematuria. A 2x2 cm bladder mass is seen which is low-grade transitional cell carcinoma. Which among the following is the ideal management?
questions.correct_answer: A. Transurethral resection of the tumor
questions.explanation:
Tumor Stage

Tis (Carcinoma in situ)

TURBT (Transurethral Resection of Bladder Tumor)

  • May be used for initial diagnosis and tumor resection if not already performed

Intravesical BCG

  • Induction: Weekly for 6 weeks
  • Maintenance: Weekly for 3 weeks at months 3, 6, 12, 18, 24, 30, and 36

Continue BCG Maintenance Therapy

  • Up to 3 years

Ta (Non-muscle invasive)

TURBT

  • Complete resection of tumor

Low-risk:

  • Single Instillation (SI) of Intravesical Chemotherapy (e.g., gemcitabine, mitomycin)
  • SI within 24 hours of TURBT
  • Alternative: Continuous saline bladder irrigation

Intermediate-risk:

  • Intravesical Chemotherapy (e.g., gemcitabine)
  • Induction: 6 weekly courses
  • Maintenance: Up to 1 year

T1 (Muscle invasive)

TURBT- For initial diagnosis and tumor debulking

High-risk:

  • Intravesical BCG
  • Induction: Weekly for 6 weeks
  • Maintenance: Up to 3 years

Consider Cystectomy

  • If BCG is not tolerated or ineffective- Alternative: Trimodality therapy (TURBT + Chemoradiation)

T2 (Muscle invasive)

TURBT- May be used for tumor resection and staging

Initial Treatment:

  • Consider Cystectomy
  • Alternatively, Trimodality therapy (TURBT + Chemoradiation)

Adjuvant Therapy:

  • Depending on response and tumor characteristics

T3 (Advanced muscle invasive)

Initial Treatment:

  • Cystectomy with possible neoadjuvant chemotherapy

TURBT - Often not performed if cystectomy is planned

Adjuvant Therapy:

  • Based on pathology and staging
  • Neoadjuvant therapy may continue

T4 (Locally advanced)

Initial Treatment:

  • Cystectomy
  • Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy, if not yet administered

TURBT- Typically avoided if cystectomy and neoadjuvant therapy are planned

Adjuvant Therapy:

  • Additional chemotherapy or radiation based on residual disease and staging

questions.text: Which of the following will have unilateral hydronephrosis?
questions.explanation:
Unilateral Hydronephrosis

Bilateral Hydronephrosis

Extramural Causes:

  • Advanced Malignancies
    • Colorectal cancer
    • Carcinoma cervix
    • Carcinoma Prostate
  • Retroperitoneal fibrosis
  • Retrocaval Ureter (Option D)

Congenital Causes:

  • Posterior Urethral Valve (Option B ruled out)
  • Urethral atresia (Option A ruled out)

Intramural Causes:

  • PUJ Obstruction
  • Ureterocele
  • Ureteric Stricture
  • Urothelial tumor

Acquired Causes:

  • Bladder neck stenosis
  • BPH (Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia) (Option C ruled out)
  • CA Prostate
  • Urethral strictures

Intraluminal Causes:

  • Stone
  • Papillary Slough
  • Due to:
    • Analgesic nephropathy
    • Sickle cell anemia

Unilateral Hydronephrosis

Bilateral Hydronephrosis
  • Congenital PUJ obstruction and calculus are the most common causes
  • Male to Female ratio 2:1
  • Right side kidney is affected more commonly

 

From lower urinary tract obstruction:

  • Loin pain
  • Features of bladder outlet obstruction—frequency, hesitancy, poor stream
  • Kidneys are not palpable if renal failure develops early
  • Dull aching loin pain with dragging sensation or heaviness
  • Mass in the loin which moves with respiration
  • Dietl's crisis (Intermittent Hydronephrosis): Swelling in the loin after acute renal colic, disappears after passing a large volume of urine
  • Dysuria, haematuria. If infected, fever and tenderness in the renal angle

From bilateral upper urinary tract obstruction:

  • Loin pain, mass in the loin, attacks of renal colic
  • In severe cases, features of renal failure like oliguria, edema, and hiccoughs may be present

questions.text: A 44-year-old lady presents to the hospital with a ballotable flank mass. The mass measures 4 cm on CT imaging. Urine examination shows malignant cells. What is the most appropriate management for her condition?
questions.explanation:
Management

RCCs are radio and chemo-resistant.

Surgical Management:

Partial Nephrectomy: Involves removing only the tumor while preserving the remainder of the kidney. (Option A)

Indications:

  • T1 Disease(<7cm)
  • Restricted to poles
  • RCC in solitary functioning kidney

Radical Nephrectomy: Involves removal of the kidney with Gerota’s fascia, para-aortic nodes, and ureter up to the pelvic brim. (Option C ruled out)

Indications: Larger tumors or when partial nephrectomy is not feasible

Ablative Techniques

Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA) and Cryoablation: Involve destroying the tumor using extreme temperatures.

Indications:

  • Patients who are not surgical candidates
  • Patients with small tumors(T1a lesions) (usually <4 cm).

Systemic Therapy

(For advanced/ metastatic disease)

Targeted Therapy

  • Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., sunitinib, pazopanib)
  • mTOR inhibitors (e.g., everolimus)

Immunotherapy: Immune checkpoint inhibitors (e.g., nivolumab)

questions.text: Which of the following is the recommended treatment for the condition shown in the image, where the size of the stone is 1.5 cm?
What is the initial management approach for urinary symptoms in a patient with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)?
questions.explanation:
Management

Medical Management
  • 1st line management: ⍺ 1 Blocker
    • Prazosin
    • Terazosin
    • Silodosin
    • Most commonly used: Tamsulosin (⍺ 1A selective Blocker) (Option B)
  • 2nd line: 5 𝛼 Reductase inhibitors
    • Finasteride (Option C ruled out)
    • Dutasteride
    • Triptorelin pamoate
  • Combination treatment with ⍺ 1 Blocker and 5 𝛼 Reductase inhibitors are used in large prostate.

Surgical Management
  • Indications:
    • No improvement in medical management.
    • Acute retention of urine
    • Chronic urinary retention with residual urine of more than 200 ml.
    • Complications like hydroureter, hydronephrosis, stone formation, recurrent infection, and gross haematuria
  • Surgeries:
    • Gold standard- TURP (Trans urethral resection of prostate). (Option A ruled out)
    • Trans urethral incision of prostate (TUIP)
    • Open prostatectomy procedures

Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)

Etiopathogenesis

  • Role of hormones in BPH:
    • DHT (Dihydrotestosterone)
      • DHT, derived from testosterone via 5-alpha reductase, binds to androgen receptors in the prostate, promoting cellular proliferation and contributing to prostatic enlargement.
    • Estrogen
      • Estrogen levels increase relative to testosterone in aging men, influencing prostate growth through activation of estrogen receptors, particularly ER-α, in the prostatic tissue.
  • Affects both glandular epithelium and connective tissue stroma to variable degrees.
  • Most common site of origin: submucosal glands of periurethral transitional zone
  • Secondary changes in the bladder (due to increased force of contraction of detrusor muscles):
    • Collagen deposition
    • Detrusor muscle hyperplasia
    • Detrusor muscle hypertrophy.

Clinical features
  • Age affected: Men over 50 years
  • Common cause of bladder outflow obstruction (BOO) in men more than 70 years of age: BPH
  • Obstructive symptoms:
    • Poor flow/stream
    • Hesitancy
    • Intermittency
    • Incomplete voiding-High post-void residual urine
    • Dribbling of urine
  • Irritative symptoms:
    • Frequency
    • Urgency
    • Nocturia

Investigations

  • Urine microscopy and C/S.
  • Ultrasound abdomen- residual urine and prostate size.
  • Uroflowmetry (Qmax):
    • Normal: > 15 ml/sec.
    • Equivocal: 10-15 ml.
    • Low: <10 ml
  • Cystometry:
    • Voiding pressure
    • Normal: <60 cm of H₂O
    • Equivocal: 60- 80 cm of H₂O
    • High: >80 cm of H₂O
  • Prostate-specific antigen (PSA)

Complications

  • Retention
  • Haematuria
  • Urinary infection
  • Stone formation

questions.text: Which of the following are true about nephroblastoma except:

options.label: A
options.text: Treatment is chemotherapy followed by surgery

options.label: D
options.text: Most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children

questions.correct_answer: D. Most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children
questions.explanation:
Cause

Caused by mutations in WT1 and WT2 genes on chromosome 11.

Associated syndromes

  • Denys-Drash Syndrome (DDS): A rare genetic disorder caused by mutations in the WT1 gene, characterized by a triad of Wilms' tumor, nephrotic syndrome due to diffuse mesangial sclerosis, and male pseudohermaphroditism
  • WAGR Syndrome: A rare genetic condition caused by a deletion on chromosome 11p13, leading to a combination of Wilms' tumor, aniridia (absence of the iris), genitourinary abnormalities, and intellectual disability.
  • Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome (BWS): A genetic disorder characterized by overgrowth, increased tumor risk, macroglossia, abdominal wall defects, and hemihyperplasia, often due to abnormalities on chromosome 11p15.5.
  • Perlman Syndrome: A rare genetic disorder characterized by overgrowth, developmental delay, intellectual disability, distinctive facial features, and an increased risk of Wilms' tumor, often caused by mutations in the DIS3L2 gene.

Clinical Presentation
  • Most common malignant pediatric renal tumor.

Triad:

  • Asymptomatic abdominal mass (MC presentation)
  • Fever (disappears after tumor resection)
  • Hematuria (Gross/Microscopic)

Rarely: Pain

Investigations

USG- Primary investigation

CECT- Investigation of choice.

MRI - For better soft tissue visualization.

Treatment

Chemotherapy followed by surgery. (Option A ruled out)

Multimodal approach

  • Surgery: Radical nephrectomy or nephron-sparing surgery
  • Chemotherapy: VCD regimen

Vincristine, Cyclophosphamide, Dactinomycin/Doxorubicin

  • Radiation therapy: For higher stages or unfavorable histology

Staging

I. Disease confined to the kidney and completely resectable

II. Tumor extends beyond the kidney but can be excised completely

Ill. Residual disease after resection with positive lymph nodes and massive spillage

IV. Blood-borne metastasis

V. Bilateral disease

Prognosis

Most important Prognostic Factor - Histology > Stage

Metastasis

Mainly through a hematogenous route into: (Option C ruled out)

  • Lungs (MC) (Option B ruled out)
  • Liver
  • Bones (Rarely)

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents to the surgical OPD with a painless left inguinal reducible mass. On examination cough impulse is positive. After further investigations, the patient is diagnosed with an inguinal hernia. What is the surgical management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Bassini's Repair:

  • Involves suturing the internal oblique, transversus abdominis, and fascia transversalis to the inguinal ligament. Known as a triple-layer repair.
  • Higher recurrence rates.

 

Shouldice Repair: involves a four-layer repair (double breasting of fascia transversalis), resulting in lower recurrence rates compared to Bassini's.

 

Modified Shouldice: A six-layer repair, including additional layers for reinforcement.

questions.text: A male patient presented with complaints of hematuria and recurrent urinary tract infection. You notice the following finding in his CT. What is the likely condition indicated by the arrow in the image?
questions.explanation:
Horseshoe Kidney

It is a congenital condition in which the two kidneys are fused at the lower ends, forming a U-shaped structure.

Cause

  • During fetal development the kidneys fuse at their lower poles, forming a U-shaped structure.
  • This fusion results in the inferior mesenteric artery preventing the ascent of the isthmus of the kidney to its normal position in the abdomen, leading to an abnormal location lower in the abdomen.

Clinical Features
  • Mostly asymptomatic.
  • Pain: due to obstruction or renal stones.
  • Recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs)
  • Hydronephrosis
  • Hematuria
  • Rovsing's syndrome: Hyperextension of the spine- nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain.

Investigation

  • CT Angiography (CT Angio): This is the investigation of choice for diagnosing a horseshoe kidney, as it allows for detailed visualization of the renal anatomy, the abnormal vascular supply, and associated complications.

CT Abdomen showing Horseshoe kidney

  • Contrast-Enhanced CT (CECT): Used when CT Angio is not available
  • Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP) - characteristic findings include:
    • Medial Orientation of Calyces: Referred to as the "Hand Joining Sign."
    • High Insertion of Ureters with Anterior Transposition: This creates a "Flower Vase" appearance of the ureters.

 

 

Management

  • Asymptomatic Patients: Typically do not require treatment, but should be monitored periodically.
  • Symptomatic Patients:
    • UPJ Obstruction: Surgical intervention such as pyeloplasty
    • Kidney Stones: Management may include conservative measures like increased fluid intake, medical therapy, or surgical removal
    • UTIs: Treated with antibiotics, and preventive measures may be considered if infections are recurrent.
    • Isthmus Management: The isthmus of the horseshoe kidney should not be divided surgically as it contains functional renal tissue.
    • Pregnancy Considerations: A horseshoe kidney can lead to dystocia (difficult labor) due to the kidney's abnormal position.

questions.text: Which is the correct sequence for the correction of hypospadias? Urethroplasty Penile de-gloving Orthoplasty Glanuloplasty

A 30-year-old male patient presents with a pelvic fracture following blunt abdominal trauma. No blood is seen at the meatus. Catheterisation does not produce significant urine output. The radiological image is given below. What is the next step in management?

options.label: D
options.text: Pelvic packing along with B/L percutaneous nephrostomy

questions.explanation:
Intraperitoneal Bladder Rupture

Involves a tear or injury to the peritoneum over the bladder, and urine leaks into the peritoneal cavity in males.

Causes

Often occurs in a fully distended bladder, usually due to trauma or injury

Clinical Features
  • Sudden, severe pain in the suprapubic region.
  • Signs of shock and syncope.
  • Diffuse abdominal pain with later features of peritonitis.
  • Abdominal distension.
  • Haematuria
  • Absence of desire to urinate

Diagnosis
  • Plain X-ray: It may show a ground glass appearance.
  • Peritoneal Tap: Used to collect urine from the abdominal cavity.
  • Cystography: Iodine dye is injected via a catheter to visualise bladder tears and the dye entry into the peritoneal cavity. The contrast outlines the bowel loops.
  • Ultrasound: To assess other abdominal injuries.

Treatment
  • Emergency Laparotomy is required. (Option C).
  • Bladder tear is sutured with polylactic acid (vicryl) in two layers.
  • Peritoneal wash to clean out the peritoneal cavity.
  • Separate drainage for prevesical space and peritoneal cavity.
  • Administration of specific antibiotics to prevent sepsis.
  • Catheterisation:
    • Malecot’s catheter is placed suprapubically.
    • Foley's catheter passed urethrally.

Complications
  • Cystitis /and pyelonephritis.
  • Peritonitis.
  • Pelvic abscess.
  • Fistula formation (vesicovaginal or rectovesical).
  • Paralytic ileus.
  • Hemorrhage.

Extra Peritoneal bladder rupture

Intra Peritoneal bladder rupture
  • Caused by pelvic fractures and rapid deceleration.
  • Leakage into thighs, perineum, penis, anterior abdominal wall.
  • Commonly associated with pelvic fractures.
  • Pelvic molar tooth sign: Contrast media leaking from the bladder and accumulating in the preperitoneal space, creating a molar tooth-shaped appearance on CT cystography after extraperitoneal bladder rupture.
  • Occurs at the bladder dome, above the peritoneal reflection.
  • Caused by a direct blow to a distended bladder.
  • Urine leakage into the abdomen causes metabolic derangements.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a young girl who presents with continuous dribbling of urine despite voiding normally, as reported by her parents, who mention her never being completely dry since birth?
questions.explanation: Correct answer A) Ectopic u

questions.text: A 1-month-old child is brought to the OPD for consultation regarding an empty scrotal sac. On examination B/L inguinal masses are palpable. What is the next step of management for this child?

options.label: B
options.text: Surgical exploration within the next 2 weeks

options.label: D
options.text: Wait and watch for spontaneous descent within the next 6 months.

questions.correct_answer: D. Wait and watch for spontaneous descent within the next 6 months.
questions.explanation:
Correct answer D) Wait and watch for spontaneous descent within the next 6 months

Undescended Testis (Cryptorchidism)

Definition

Cryptorchidism is a condition where one or both testes fail to descend into the scrotum from the abdomen.

Locations
  • Inguinal/Palpable undescended testis: 80%
  • Abdominal/Non-Palpable undescended testis: 20%

Causes and Associated Conditions
  • Developmental and Genetic Factors: Conditions like Klinefelter syndrome and testosterone imbalances can impair testicular descent.
  • Prematurity and Maternal Factors: Premature birth and maternal issues like diabetes or medication exposure can lead to undescended testes.
  • Mechanical and Physical Factors: Obstructions in the inguinal canal, scrotum, or related conditions such as inguinal hernia can prevent normal testicular descent.

Complications

(SATHI Mnemonic):

  • S: Sterility - Elevated abdominal temperature can impair sperm production, leading to potential infertility if untreated.
  • A: Atrophy - Prolonged exposure to heat can cause the testis to shrink or become non-functional.
  • T: Trauma, Tumor, Torsion - Increased risk of testicular torsion, which can cause severe pain and potentially result in testicular loss. The most common tumor associated is seminoma with the highest risk of tumor development in abdominal testes.
  • H: Hernia - Over 90% of cases are associated with a patent processus vaginalis, increasing the risk of inguinal hernia.
  • I: Inflammation - The undescended testis is more prone to inflammatory conditions.

Note: Leydig cells are unaffected, maintaining secondary sexual characteristics, while Sertoli cells are impaired, affecting spermatogenesis.

Diagnosis
  • Palpable undescended testis: Inguinal exploration.
  • Non-Palpable undescended testis: Diagnostic laparoscopy.
  • Imaging: Ultrasound or MRI may be utilized to locate the testis.

Treatment

Surgical Repositioning (Orchidopexy): Usually performed when the child is between 6-12 months old. (Option D)

Types of Orchidopexy

  • Ombridannes
  • Keetley-Torek
  • Stephen-Fowler
  • Ladd & Gross

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of radiolucent renal stone?
questions.explanation:
Stone Type

Features

Image

Calcium Oxalate
  • The most common type of stone (60–85% of all stones); Radiopaque
  • Associated with hypercalciuria, hypercalcaemia, hyperoxaluria, hyperuricosuria, and hypocitraturia
  • Types: monohydrate (dumbbell-shaped) , dihydrate (envelope shaped)

​

​​​

​​

Calcium Phosphate
  • Pure calcium phosphate stones are rare
  • Types include apatite and brushite stones
  • Apatite stones are seen with infection; brushite stones are associated with distal renal tubular acidosis.

​

​​

Struvite
  • Aka staghorn calculi / Triple phosphate stone (Ca, Mg, NH4+, Phosphate)
  • Radiopaque
  • Infection stones that form in alkaline urine due to urease-producing bacteria (e.g., Proteus, Klebsiella, Serratia, Enterobacter)

​​

​​ ​​

Cystine
  • Radiopaque, Constitute approximately 1% of stones
  • Result from cystinuria, an autosomal recessive inherited disease that causes decreased reabsorption of cystine.
  • Very hard stones due to disulfide bonds

Uric Acid
  • Radiolucent
  • Promoted by hyperuricosuria, which can be caused by conditions like gout and myeloproliferative disorders
  • Precipitates in acidic urine and remains soluble in alkaline urine.

​

questions.text: For which of the following conditions is the Whitaker test recommended?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer A) Hydronephrosis

Feature

Details

Definition

A urodynamic test that measures the pressure gradient between the renal pelvis and bladder to assess upper urinary tract obstruction.

Indications

Equivocal cases of upper urinary tract obstruction, PUJ obstruction, post-pyeloplasty evaluation, distinguishing true obstruction from hydronephrosis.

Procedure

1. Percutaneous nephrostomy placed in the renal pelvis.

2. Bladder catheter inserted for pressure measurement.

3. Fluid infusion into renal pelvis at 10 ml/min.

4. Pressure difference between renal pelvis & bladder recorded.

Interpretation

<15 cm H₂O → No obstruction.

15–22 cm H₂O → Indeterminate (needs further evaluation).

>22 cm H₂O → Significant obstruction present.

Advantages

Helps differentiate true obstruction vs. non-obstructive dilation.

Useful in post-surgical cases.

Limitations

Invasive (rarely used due to modern imaging).

Replaced by diuretic renal scan (DTPA/EC scan) & MR Urography.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man was referred to the surgery OPD from the infertility clinic. On palpation, a bag of worms sensation was felt with dilated veins. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Varicocele

Common Occurrence
  • More common in tall, thin young men
  • More frequent on the left side but can be bilateral

Causes
  • Idiopathic
  • Absence or incompetent valve at the junction of the left testicular vein and left renal vein
  • Perpendicular entry of the left testicular vein into the left renal vein
  • Left-sided renal cell carcinoma causing blockage of the left testicular vein

Effects
  • Increased temperature in the scrotum, depressing spermatogenesis and causing infertility

Symptoms
  • Swelling at the root of the scrotum
  • Dragging pain in the groin and scrotum
  • "Bag of worms" feeling
  • Impulse on coughing
  • Swelling reduces on lying down (except in renal cell carcinoma)

Investigations
  • Venous Doppler of the scrotum and groin
  • Ultrasound of the abdomen to check for kidney tumours
  • Semen analysis

Treatment

  • Palomo's Operation: Suprainguinal extraperitoneal ligation of the testicular vein
  • Ligation of veins
  • Excision of veins

questions.explanation:

Radical Nephrectomy: Involves removal of the kidney with Gerota’s fascia, para-aortic nodes, and ureter up to the pelvic brim.

Indications: Larger tumours or when partial nephrectomy is not feasible

Ablative Techniques

Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA) and Cryoablation involve destroying the tumour using extreme temperatures.

Indications:

  • Patients who are not surgical candidates
  • Patients with small tumours (T1a lesions) (usually <4 cm).

Systemic Therapy

(For advanced/ metastatic disease)

Targeted Therapy

  • Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., sunitinib, pazopanib)
  • mTOR inhibitors (e.g., everolimus)

Immunotherapy: Immune checkpoint inhibitors (e.g., nivolumab)

questions.explanation: Correct answer D) Metastasizing testicular tu

questions.text: A 10-month-old male baby presented with an empty scrotum. Ultrasonography revealed that the right testis was found in the right inguinal canal, while the left testis was found in the perineum. Comment on the diagnosis of this baby.

options.label: C
options.text: Right-side undescended testis and left-sided ectopic testis

options.label: D
options.text: Right side ectopic testis and left side undescended testis

questions.correct_answer: C. Right-side undescended testis and left-sided ectopic testis

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 14-year-old boy who is experiencing sudden scrotal pain, where physical examination reveals a swollen and red scrotum with the right testes being retracted, absent cremasteric reflex, and negative Prehn's sign?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer C) Right testicu

Direction of Rotation
  • Right Testis: Rotates clockwise
  • Left Testis: Rotates counterclockwise

Predisposing Factors
  • Inversion of the Testis
  • High Investment in Tunica Vaginalis
  • Gap Between Testis and Epididymis
  • Heavy Straining

Features
  • Age Group: Common in children and adolescents
  • Symptoms: Sudden onset of pain in the scrotum, groin, and lower abdomen; vomiting due to pylorospasm
  • Signs: Tenderness, redness, and edema of the scrotal skin
  • Deming's Sign: Affected testis is positioned high due to twisting and cremaster muscle spasm
  • Angell's Sign: Opposite testis lies horizontally due to the presence of mesorchium

Investigations
  • WBC Count: Elevated levels
  • Doppler Study: To assess testicular artery pulsation
  • Ultrasound Abdomen

Treatment
  • Emergency Exploration: Scrotum exploration and untwisting of the testis. The viability of the testis is checked.
  • Fixation: If viable, the testis is fixed to the scrotal sac with 2-3 interrupted nonabsorbable sutures (Prolene).
  • Timing: If surgery occurs within 12-24 hours, viability may be retained. Any delay can lead to gangrene, requiring orchidectomy.
  • Orchidectomy Consideration: If in doubt, the testis can be retained temporarily, with orchidectomy postponed to assess viability.
  • Postoperative Care: A repeat Doppler study confirms viability. The opposite testis should also be fixed to prevent torsion.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for an elderly male patient who has come to the hospital with lower back pain, a movable mass in the lower back that becomes more prominent when breathing in and a general feeling of weakness? The lab tests show the presence of red blood cells in the urine, with no sign of pus cells.
questions.explanation: Correct answer C) Renal

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 60-year-old male who is experiencing lower back pain and has sclerotic lesions in the vertebrae?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Pathophysiology

Prostate cancer spreads hematogenously to bones, commonly affecting the spine, pelvis, ribs, and femur. Metastases are osteoblastic (sclerotic) due to increased osteoblast activity.

Common Symptoms

Lower back pain, pathological fractures, urinary symptoms (hesitancy, frequency), and neurological deficits if spinal cord compression occurs.

Laboratory Findings

PSA – Elevated, ALP – Elevated (bone involvement), Serum Calcium – Normal/mildly elevated (osteoblastic metastases do not cause severe hypercalcemia).

X-ray Findings

Sclerotic (osteoblastic) lesions in vertebrae, pelvis, and long bones.

Bone Scan (Tc-99m)

Shows increased radiotracer uptake in metastatic sites (best for early detection).

MRI Spine

Detects spinal cord compression marrow infiltration.

CT Pelvis/Spine

Defines bone metastases and local spread.

Confirmatory Test

TRUS-guided prostate biopsy (Transrectal Ultrasound Biopsy).

Treatment

Androgen Deprivation Therapy (ADT) (GnRH agonists like Leuprolide), Bisphosphonates for bone health, Radiation for spinal metastases, and Surgical decompression if cord compression occurs.

questions.text: A patient with a history of trauma has a ruptured bulbar urethra. What is the location for the accumulation of urine?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer A) Superficial pouch

Feature

Anterior Urethral Injury

Posterior Urethral Injury

Location
  • Bulbar urethra (most common)
  • Penile urethra

 

 
  • Membranous urethra (bulbomembranous junction most common)
  • Prostatic urethra

 

 

Common Causes
  • Straddle injuries
  • Direct trauma
  • Iatrogenic injuries (catheterization, cystoscopy)
  • Penetrating trauma (stab/gunshot wounds)
  • Pelvic fractures (often due to motor vehicle accidents)
  • Blunt trauma

Clinical Features
  • Hematuria (blood in urine)
  • Penile/perineal bruising (butterfly-shaped hematoma)
  • Perineal pain
  • Urinary retention or difficulty voiding
  • Possible swelling of the penis or scrotum due to hematoma
  • Blood at the meatus
  • Inability to void
  • High-riding prostate on rectal exam
  • Perineal or suprapubic pain
  • Pelvic hematoma associated with pelvic fractures
  • Possible concomitant bladder injury

Investigations
  • Retrograde Urethrography (RGU): Gold standard, shows the extent and location of the injury
  • Voiding Cystourethrography (VCUG): Used to assess urethral patency post-repair
  • Ultrasound: Can detect hematoma or associated injuries
  • Retrograde Urethrography (RGU): Gold standard for initial assessment
  • CT Urethrography: Useful in evaluating complex injuries
  • Pelvic CT Scan: Important for associated pelvic fractures
  • Cystoscopy: Sometimes performed for further evaluation
  • If injury at Prostatomembranous junction - High lying prostate → On IVP- Pie in-sky appearance

questions.text: In a newborn male with an undeveloped scrotum, the testis was observed to be located near the peritoneum. Which of the following factors aids in the descent of the testis into the scrotum?

options.label: D
options.text: Manually bring the testis down to the bottom of scrotum.

questions.explanation:
Correct answer A) GnRH Analogu

Undescended Testis (Cryptorchidism)

Definition
  • Cryptorchidism is a condition where one or both testes fail to descend into the scrotum from the abdomen.

Locations
  • Inguinal/Palpable undescended testis: 80%
  • Abdominal/Non-Palpable undescended testis: 20%

Causes and Associated Conditions
  • Developmental and Genetic Factors: Conditions like Klinefelter syndrome and testosterone imbalances can impair testicular descent.
  • Prematurity and Maternal Factors: Premature birth and maternal issues like diabetes or medication exposure can lead to undescended testes.
  • Mechanical and Physical Factors: Obstructions in the inguinal canal, scrotum, or related conditions such as inguinal hernia can prevent normal testicular descent.

Complications

(SATHI Mnemonic):

  • S: Sterility - Elevated abdominal temperature can impair sperm production, leading to potential infertility if untreated.
  • A: Atrophy - Prolonged exposure to heat can cause the testis to shrink or become non-functional.
  • T: Trauma, Tumor, Torsion - Increased risk of testicular torsion, which can cause severe pain and potentially result in testicular loss. The most common tumor associated is seminoma, with the highest risk of tumor development in abdominal testes.
  • H: Hernia - Over 90% of cases are associated with a patent processus vaginalis, increasing the risk of inguinal hernia.
  • I: Inflammation - The undescended testis is more prone to inflammatory conditions.

Note: Leydig cells are unaffected, maintaining secondary sexual characteristics, while Sertoli cells are impaired, affecting spermatogenesis.

Diagnosis
  • Palpable undescended testis: Inguinal exploration.
  • Non-Palpable undescended testis: Diagnostic laparoscopy.
  • Imaging: Ultrasound or MRI may be utilised to locate the testis.

Treatment

Surgical Repositioning (Orchidopexy): Usually performed when the child is between 6-12 months old.

Types of Orchidopexy

  • Ombridannes
  • Keetley-Torek
  • Stephen-Fowler
  • Ladd & Gross

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with scrotal enlargement. His LDH levels are notably elevated, while HCG and alpha-fetoprotein levels remain within normal ranges. Upon histopathological examination, the findings are as shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Details

Tumor Type

Seminoma, the most common pure testicular germ cell tumour in men aged 25-45

Origin

Germinal epithelium of the seminiferous tubules

Clinical Features

Painless, firm swelling or mass in the testicle, typically unilateral. Accounts for 50% of all testicular germ cell tumors. 10% have secondary hydrocele, 5% have gynecomastia

Diagnostic Markers

AFP: Normal

hCG: Normal or mildly elevated

LDH: Elevated

Investigation

Ultrasound: Homogeneous, hypoechoic mass

Histology: Sheets of oval cells with clear cytoplasm, large nuclei with prominent acidophilic nucleoli

 

FNAC: Contraindicated due to the risk of tumour cell seeding and lymph node metastasis

Treatment

Primary: High Inguinal Radical Orchidectomy

Adjuvant: Radiation therapy or chemotherapy for positive lymph nodes

questions.explanation: Correct Option B) Retrograde ejacu

questions.text: All the following are features of polycystic disease of kidneys except:
questions.explanation:
Feature

Explanation

Hematuria

Due to rupture of cysts into the renal collecting system

Hypertension

Result of renin-angiotensin system (RAS) activation due to ischemia from cyst compression

Renal failure

Progressive cyst expansion leads to nephron loss, causing chronic kidney disease (CKD)

Erythrocytosis (Absent)

CKD leads to decreased erythropoietin (EPO), resulting in anemia rather than polycythemia

Characteristics

ADPKD

ARPKD

Affected age group

Adults

Children

Cysts

Are present in both outer and inner surfaces

Present only on the inner surface.

Involved gene
  • PKD 1 on chromosome 16
  • PKD 2 on chromosome 4

PKHD on chromosome 6

(Statement 2)

Protein affected

polycystin

Fibrocystin (Statement 3)

Histology

Complications
  • Coronary or hypertensive heart disease (40%). (Statement 4)
  • Infection (25%).
  • Ruptured berry aneurysm or hypertensive intracerebral haemorrhage (15%).
  • Neonatal period:
    • Respiratory failure due to pulmonary hypoplasia.
    • Renal failure.
  • Childhood and adolescence:
    • Progressive renal failure leading to ESRD.
    • Complications of CKD.
    • Complications from hepatic fibrosis.

Images

questions.text: A 20-year-old was brought to the ER after falling off his bicycle. His vitals were stable, but he had a bruise over the perineum, and he had not passed urine yet. Blood was seen at the meatus and the bladder was not palpable. How do you manage him?

questions.text: What is the primary reason for bladder outlet obstruction in male children?

A mother notices a swelling in the abdomen of her 3-year-old child while bathing him. He had a history of hematuria two weeks back, which resolved spontaneously. On examination, a right–sided reniform ballotable mass was found. What investigations will you do? 1. CECT 2. PET-CT 3. 24 hour urinary VMA 4. FNAC
questions.explanation:
Investigation

Role in Diagnosis

Justification

CECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT Scan)

First-line imaging for renal tumors

Determines tumor size, extent, local invasion, and vascular involvement (e.g., renal vein or IVC thrombus).

PET-CT (Positron Emission Tomography-CT)

Staging and metastasis detection

Helps assess lymph node involvement, lung, liver, and bone metastases. Also differentiates Wilms tumor vs. neuroblastoma.

24-hour urinary VMA (Vanillylmandelic Acid)

Differentiates Wilms tumor from Neuroblastoma

Neuroblastoma (adrenal origin) → elevated VMA levels; Wilms tumor does not produce catecholamines.

FNAC (Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology)

Not recommended

Contraindicated in Wilms tumor due to risk of tumor spillage, which can lead to peritoneal dissemination. Core biopsy may be done in unclear cases.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient came to the outpatient department with complaints of hematuria. A 2x2 cm bladder mass is seen which is low grade transitional cell carcinoma. Which among the following is the ideal management?
questions.correct_answer: A. Transurethral resection of the tumor
questions.explanation:
Correct answer A) Transurethral resection of the tumour

Tumor Stage

Tis (Carcinoma in situ)

TURBT (Transurethral Resection of Bladder Tumor)

  • May be used for initial diagnosis and tumor resection if not already performed

Intravesical BCG

  • Induction: Weekly for 6 weeks
  • Maintenance: Weekly for 3 weeks at months 3, 6, 12, 18, 24, 30, and 36

Continue BCG Maintenance Therapy

  • Up to 3 years

Ta (Non-muscle invasive)

TURBT

  • Complete resection of tumor

Low-risk:

  • Single Instillation (SI) of Intravesical Chemotherapy (e.g., gemcitabine, mitomycin)
  • SI within 24 hours of TURBT
  • Alternative: Continuous saline bladder irrigation

Intermediate-risk:

  • Intravesical Chemotherapy (e.g., gemcitabine)
  • Induction: 6 weekly courses
  • Maintenance: Up to 1 year

T1 (Muscle invasive)

TURBT- For initial diagnosis and tumor debulking

High-risk:

  • Intravesical BCG
  • Induction: Weekly for 6 weeks
  • Maintenance: Up to 3 years

Consider Cystectomy

  • If BCG is not tolerated or ineffective- Alternative: Trimodality therapy (TURBT + Chemoradiation)

T2 (Muscle invasive)

TURBT- May be used for tumor resection and staging

Initial Treatment:

  • Consider Cystectomy
  • Alternatively, Trimodality therapy (TURBT + Chemoradiation)

Adjuvant Therapy:

  • Depending on response and tumor characteristics

T3 (Advanced muscle invasive)

Initial Treatment:

  • Cystectomy with possible neoadjuvant chemotherapy

TURBT - Often not performed if cystectomy is planned

Adjuvant Therapy:

  • Based on pathology and staging
  • Neoadjuvant therapy may continue

T4 (Locally advanced)

Initial Treatment:

  • Cystectomy
  • Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy, if not yet administered

TURBT- Typically avoided if cystectomy and neoadjuvant therapy are planned

Adjuvant Therapy:

  • Additional chemotherapy or radiation based on residual disease and staging

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the condition mentioned below?

options.label: A
options.text: Patient must be started on anti-gas gangrene serum therapy

options.label: B
options.text: It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection

questions.correct_answer: B. It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection
questions.explanation:
Definition

Necrotizing infection of the soft tissues in the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region, akin to necrotizing fasciitis.

Cause

It is usually caused by mixed bacterial fora (Escherichia coli, Bacteroides spp., Streptococcus pyogenes, Staphylococcus aureus). (Option B)

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms: Intense pain in the genitalia, progressing through five phases:
    • Prodromal Phase: Fever and lethargy.
    • Early Pain Phase: Intense pain, possible oedema, pruritus.
    • Progressive Phase: Increased pain, and erythema.
    • Crepitation Phase: Dusky skin with subcutaneous crepitation.
    • Gangrene Phase: Gangrene with purulent discharge.
  • Pain may decrease as gangrene progresses.
  • Severity ranges from localised tenderness to septic shock.

Risk Factors
  • Peripheral vascular disease, diabetes mellitus, malnutrition, alcoholism, immunocompromised states.

Diagnosis
  • Clinical presentation supported by imaging or lab findings.

Management
  • Initial Treatment:
    • Fluid resuscitation.
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics.
    • Surgical debridement of necrotic tissue.
  • Additional Measures:
    • Urinary and fecal diversion to prevent wound contamination.
    • Intensive monitoring for sepsis.
    • Wound review and vacuum-assisted dressing.
    • Skin grafting post-infection control.

questions.text: In a patient with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, what is the finding shown in the image given?
A 75-year-old man with prostate carcinoma presents to you with a PSA of 9 ng/mL with a small tumour focus. His Gleason score is 6. What will be your most likely management?
questions.explanation:
Gleason

Score

Grade

Components

Cancer

Grade

Description

6

3 + 3

Low-grade

Cells resemble healthy tissue; low likelihood of growth and spread.

7

3 + 4 or 4 + 3

Intermediate-grade

Cells show more variation and moderate risk of growth and spread.

8

4 + 4, 3 + 5, or 5 + 3

High-grade

Cells look very different; higher likelihood of rapid growth and spread.

9 or 10

4 + 5, 5 + 4, or 5 + 5

Very high-grade

Cells are highly aggressive and very likely to grow and spread quickly.

Management Strategy

Key Points

Active Surveillance (Option D)

For low-risk cases, regular monitoring

Radical Prostatectomy

(Option A ruled out)

Surgery for localized cancer; potentially curative

Radiation Therapy

(Option B, C ruled out)

High-energy rays; external or brachytherapy

 

Hormone Therapy

Reduces/block testosterone; for advanced/metastatic cases

Chemotherapy

Systemic drug treatment; for advanced/metastatic cases

questions.text: A patient arrives after being involved in a motorcycle road traffic accident. The patient does not report any pain or injury. Upon examination, there is evidence of blood at the urethral meatus. What would be your subsequent course of action in terms of managing this patient?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Anterior Urethral Injury

Posterior Urethral Injury

Location
  • Bulbar urethra (most common)
  • Penile urethra

 

 
  • Membranous urethra (bulbomembranous junction most common)
  • Prostatic urethra

Common Causes
  • Straddle injuries
  • Direct trauma
  • Iatrogenic injuries (catheterisation, cystoscopy)
  • Penetrating trauma (stab/gunshot wounds)
  • Pelvic fractures (often due to motor vehicle accidents)
  • Blunt trauma

Clinical Features
  • Hematuria
  • Penile/perineal bruising (butterfly-shaped hematoma)
  • Perineal pain
  • Urinary retention or difficulty voiding
  • Possible swelling of the penis or scrotum due to hematoma
  • Blood at the meatus
  • Inability to void
  • High-riding prostate on rectal exam
  • Perineal or suprapubic pain
  • Pelvic hematoma associated with pelvic fractures
  • Possible concomitant bladder injury

Investigations
  • Retrograde Urethrography (RGU): Gold standard, shows the extent and location of the injury
  • Voiding Cystourethrography (VCUG): Used to assess urethral patency post-repair
  • Ultrasound: Can detect hematoma or associated injuries
  • Retrograde Urethrography (RGU): Gold standard for initial assessment
  • CT Urethrography: Useful in evaluating complex injuries
  • Pelvic CT Scan: Important for associated pelvic fractures
  • Cystoscopy: Sometimes performed for further evaluation
  • If injury at Prostatomembranous junction - High lying prostate → On IVP- Pie in-sky appearance.

Management

  • Minor Injuries: Managed conservatively with catheterisation or suprapubic catheter if severe bruising
  • Severe Injuries: Surgical intervention like primary repair, urethroplasty, or end-to-end anastomosis
  • Antibiotics: To prevent infection
  • Initial Management: Suprapubic catheterization for urinary diversion
  • Delayed Urethroplasty (Definitive management): 3-6 months post-injury after inflammation and fibrosis have subsided
  • Primary Realignment: Occasionally attempted if conditions permit
  • Endoscopic Realignment: For selected cases, though often reserved for acute management

Complications

  • Urethral stricture (risk of recurrence)
  • Erectile dysfunction (especially if injury near the penile base)
  • Urinary incontinence (less common)
  • Infection (urethritis or abscess formation)
  • Bladder neck contracture
  • Chronic pelvic syndrome

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a girl who has experienced continuous urinary dribbling and persistent bladder fullness since birth?
questions.explanation:
Ectopic ureter

Etiology
  • It results from abnormal embryological development, often associated with ureteral duplication.

Pathology
  • Ectopic ureters drain to sites other than the bladder, which is commonly associated with duplication of the ureter.

Pathophysiology

  • In females, ectopic ureters open below the urethral sphincter or into the vagina, leading to incontinence.

  • In males, ectopic ureters usually open above the external urethral sphincter, maintaining continence.

Types

  • Bilateral ectopic ureters (10% of cases).

  • Unilateral ectopic ureters.

Clinical Features

 

  • Females: Continuous urinary incontinence despite normal voiding.

  • Males: Typically asymptomatic or continent due to ureter opening above the sphincter.

Diagnosis

  • Computed Tomo-Urography (CTU).

  • Magnetic Resonance Urography (MRU).

Lab Investigations
  • Primarily imaging-based diagnostics (CTU or MRU).

Complications

  • Persistent incontinence in females.

  • Potential recurrent urinary tract infections.

Differential Diagnosis

  • Vesicoureteral Reflux

  • Urethral Stricture: Difficulty in urination and weak stream, not continuous incontinence.

  • Neurogenic Bladder

Treatment
  • Surgical correction: Reposition it into the bladder to restore normal continence.

questions.text: Identify the investigation and the lesion depicted in the image given below:

options.label: A
options.text: Retrograde cystourethrogram with membranous urethra stricture

options.label: B
options.text: Retrograde cystourethrogram with penile urethral stricture

options.label: D
options.text: Micturating cystourethrography with prostatic urethra stricture

questions.correct_answer: B. Retrograde cystourethrogram with penile urethral stricture
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Retrograde cystourethrogram with penile urethral stricture

Urethral Stricture

Definition

Abnormal narrowing of the urethra causes partial or complete obstruction of urine flow, leading to discomfort and severe complications if untreated.

Causes

Trauma (Most common): Pelvic fractures, falls, accidents, or iatrogenic trauma from prolonged catheterization.

Infections: STIs like gonorrhoea and chlamydia cause urethritis.

Medical Procedures: Urethral surgeries or radiation for pelvic cancers.

Inflammatory Conditions: Chronic inflammation from conditions like lichen sclerosus.

Investigations

Posterior Urethral Stricture: Micturating Cystourethrogram (MCU) to visualize the posterior urethra and bladder during voiding. (Option C & D ruled out)

Anterior Urethral Stricture: Retrograde Urethrogram (RGU).

Emergency Evaluation: Both RGU and MCU may be used in trauma cases or acute urinary retention.

Management

Urethral Dilation: Temporary relief with dilators, often leading to recurrence.

Optical Internal Urethrotomy (OIU): Endoscopic incision at the 12 o'clock position; effective for short bulbar strictures (<2 cm).

Urethroplasty: Surgical excision and reconstruction; the gold standard for recurrent or complex strictures

  • Strictures up to 2 cm: Excision with end-to-end anastomosis.
  • Strictures >2 cm: Excision and reconstruction with buccal mucosa, bladder mucosa, or penile skin.

He experiences a strong urge to urinate but is unable to do so. During examination, blood is observed at the opening of the urethra, and there is swelling of the penis and scrotum. Which specific area is affected by the injury?

Correct Answer B - Bulbar urethra injury

Feature

Anterior Urethral Injury

Location
  • Bulbar urethra (most common)
  • Penile urethra

Common Causes
  • Straddle injuries
  • Direct trauma
  • Iatrogenic injuries (catheterization, cystoscopy)

Clinical Features
  • Hematuria (blood in urine)
  • Penile/perineal bruising (butterfly-shaped hematoma)
  • Perineal pain
  • Urinary retention or difficulty voiding
  • Possible swelling of the penis or scrotum due to hematoma

Investigations
  • Retrograde Urethrography (RGU): Gold standard, shows the extent and location of injury
  • Voiding Cystourethrography (VCUG): Used to assess urethral patency post-repair
  • Ultrasound: Can detect hematoma or associated injuries

questions.text: Which of the following should be the treatment of choice for renal cell carcinoma with a tumour less than 4 cm in size?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Partial nephrectomy

Treatment of RCC: RCCs are radio and chemo-resistant (Option B & D ruled out)

Surgical Management:

Partial Nephrectomy (Option A): Involves removing only the tumour while preserving the remainder of the kidney.

Indications:

  • T1 Disease(<7cm)
  • Restricted to poles
  • RCC in solitary functioning kidney

Radical Nephrectomy: Involves removal of the kidney with Gerota’s fascia, para-aortic nodes, and ureter up to the pelvic brim.

Indications: Larger tumours or when partial nephrectomy is not feasible (Option C ruled out)

Ablative Techniques

Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA) and Cryoablation involve destroying the tumour using extreme temperatures.

Indications:

  • Patients who are not surgical candidates
  • Patients with small tumours (T1a lesions) (usually <4 cm).

Systemic Therapy

(For advanced/ metastatic disease)

Targeted Therapy

  • Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., sunitinib, pazopanib)
  • mTOR inhibitors (e.g., everolimus)

Immunotherapy: Immune checkpoint inhibitors (e.g., nivolumab)

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented to his primary care physician with a 3-month history of increasing urinary frequency without burning and nocturia four times each day. He has limited his fluid consumption and caffeine intake in the evening without much benefit. On prostate examination, the swelling was palpated with a smooth surface, and a firm, non-tender rubber-like consistency was found. The physician thinks of benign prostate hypertrophy. All are characteristic features of benign prostate hypertrophy except:
questions.correct_answer: A. Increased trabeculations in the bladder
questions.explanation:
Benign Prostate Hyperplasia (BPH)

Explanation
  • Age affected: Men over 50 years
  • After 60 years, 50% of men have histological evidence of BPH.
  • Common cause of significant lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) in men: BPH
  • Common cause of bladder outflow obstruction (BOO) in men more than 70 years of age: BPH

Etiopathogenesis
  • Role of hormones in BPH:
    • DHT (Dihydrotestosterone)
      • DHT, derived from testosterone via 5-alpha reductase, binds to androgen receptors in the prostate, promoting cellular proliferation and contributing to prostatic enlargement.
    • Estrogen
      • Estrogen levels increase relative to testosterone in ageing men, influencing prostate growth through the activation of estrogen receptors, particularly ER-α, in the prostatic tissue.
  • Affects both glandular epithelium and connective tissue stroma to variable degrees.

Common site of origin

Submucosal glands of the periurethral transitional zone

Secondary changes in the bladder

It is due to increased force of contraction of detrusor muscles):

  • Collagen deposition
  • Detrusor muscle hyperplasia
  • Detrusor muscle hypertrophy.

Clinical features
  • Obstructive symptoms:
    • Poor flow/stream
    • Hesitancy
    • Intermittency
    • Incomplete voiding-High post-void residual urine
    • Dribbling of urine
  • Irritative symptoms:
    • Frequency
    • Urgency
    • Nocturia

Complications
  • Retention
  • Haematuria
  • Urinary infection
  • Stone formation
  • Hydronephrosis

questions.explanation:
Management of renal stones

Medical management

Surgical Management
  • Analgesics like diclofenac, ketorolac, tramadol
  • Fluid therapy: IVF (intravenous fluids) are administered to prevent dehydration
  • Alpha 1 blocker: Tamsulosin (relaxes ureter and expels the stone).
  • Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL): Indicated if the size of the calculi <2 cm. (Contraindicated in pregnancy and bleeding diathesis). (Option A ruled out)
  • PCNL (Percutaneous nephrolithotomy): If the size is >2 cm. (Option B)
  • Ureteroscopy
  • Retrograde intrarenal surgery
  • Pyelolithotomy and nephrolithotomy (rarely used).
