questions.text: A 35-year-old man suffered a blow on a distended bladder ,following which he developed sudden severe pain in the hypogastrium associated with syncope. Later on, as the pain subsided, the abdomen began to distend. However, he had no desire to micturate. Which among the following is true regarding his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: This is a typical case of extraperitoneal bladder rupture

options.label: B
options.text: MRI is the ideal investigation to diagnose bladder rupture

options.label: C
options.text: Repair is done by suturing edges with single-layer 2/0 absorbable suture

options.label: D
options.text: Laparoscopic method is avoided as it can be done only on laparotomy

questions.correct_answer: A. This is a typical case of extraperitoneal bladder rupture
questions.explanation:
Extra peritoneal bladder rupture

Definition

It occurs when the bladder wall is disrupted, but the peritoneal lining remains intact, often due to trauma.

Investigations

(Option B ruled out)
  • CT cystography reveals characteristic features like a flame-shaped appearance, pear sign & teardrop appearance.
  • Retrograde cystography is the imaging modality of choice for diagnosing bladder ruptures, including extraperitoneal injuries.
  • Extravasation of contrast limited to the perivesical space is a key finding that helps differentiate extraperitoneal from intraperitoneal ruptures, where contrast would outline bowel loops.

Management
  • Initial management:
    • Urethral catheterisation with free bladder drainage for 10-14 days.
    • Followed by a cystogram to confirm healing before catheter removal.
  • If the injury is iatrogenic:
    • Repair during the same procedure (open or laparoscopic).
    • Repair done in two layers using 2/0 vicryl absorbable sutures (Option C ruled out)
  • Bladder injury with pelvic fracture:
    • The bladder should be repaired at the same time during the surgery for pelvic fracture.
    • Immediate surgical repair is indeed indicated in cases where there are complicating factors like intravesical bone spicules, bladder neck injuries, or associated vaginal or rectal lacerations.
    • Laparoscopy can be used in the management of bladder rupture, particularly in cases where less invasive approaches are preferred (Option D ruled out).

questions.text: An 11-month-old boy had a recent urinary tract infection that was resolved with antibiotics. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination revealed an empty scrotum on the right side with normal left testis. However, a mass was palpable on the right inguinal canal. The USG revealed the right testicle under the subcutaneous fat near the right inguinal canal, as shown in the image below. What is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation:
Undescended Testis (Cryptorchidism)

Definition

It is a condition where one or both testes fail to descend into the scrotum from the abdomen.

Locations
  • Inguinal/Palpable undescended testis: 80%
  • Abdominal/Non-Palpable undescended testis: 20%

Diagnosis
  • Palpable undescended testis: Inguinal exploration. (Option D)
  • Non-Palpable undescended testis: Diagnostic laparoscopy. (Option B ruled out)
  • Imaging: Ultrasound or MRI may be utilised to locate the testis.

Treatment

Surgical Repositioning (Orchidopexy): Usually performed when the child is between 6-12 months old. (Option C ruled out)

 

Types of Orchidopexy

  • Ombridannes
  • Keetley-Torek
  • Stephen-Fowler
  • Ladd & Gross

questions.text: What should be the initial course of action for a patient who has presented with a pelvic fracture and a rupture in the membranous urethra?

options.label: A
options.text: A suprapubic catheter should be inserted as soon as possible

questions.correct_answer: A. A suprapubic catheter should be inserted as soon as possible
questions.explanation:
Investigations, Management & Complications of Posterior Urethral Injuries

Investigations
  • Retrograde Urethrography (RGU): Gold standard for initial assessment
  • CT Urethrography: Useful in evaluating complex injuries
  • Pelvic CT Scan: Important for associated pelvic fractures
  • Cystoscopy: Sometimes performed for further evaluation
  • If injury at Prostatomembranous junction - High lying prostate → On IVP- Pie in-sky appearance

Management
  • Initial Management: Suprapubic catheterisation for urinary diversion
  • Delayed Urethroplasty (Definitive management): 3-6 months post-injury after inflammation and fibrosis have subsided (Option B ruled out)
  • Primary Realignment: Occasionally attempted if conditions permit
  • Endoscopic Realignment: For selected cases, though often reserved for acute management

Complications
  • Urethral stricture (most common long-term complication)
  • Urinary incontinence (due to sphincter damage)
  • Erectile dysfunction (common due to injury near neurovascular structures)
  • Bladder neck contracture
  • Chronic pelvic syndrome

questions.text: What is the cause of the following appearance in IVP?
questions.explanation:
Ureterocoele

Types
  • Simple Ureterocele (Intravesical - 20%): Found entirely within the bladder and associated with a single ureter. It is less complex and easier to manage.
  • Ectopic Ureterocele (80%): Extends beyond the bladder and often involves a duplicated ureter. This is more complicated due to its location, which may involve the bladder, neck, or urethra.

Etiology

Congenital anomaly is caused by an obstruction in the development of the distal ureter during fetal growth, leading to cystic dilation at the ureteral orifice.

Clinical Features
  • Recurrent Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs)/ Urosepsis.
  • Unilateral Hydroureteronephrosis.
  • Palpable Abdominal Mass: Particularly in children, where a distended bladder or large ureterocele might be felt as a mass.

Investigations
  • Ultrasound (USG): The first-line imaging modality revealing hydroureteronephrosis and a cystic structure in the bladder.
  • Micturating Cystourethrogram (MCU): Demonstrates a filling defect in the bladder caused by the ureterocele.
  • Cystoscopy: Allows direct visualisation of the ureterocele as a cystic structure that enlarges and collapses with urine flow in the bladder.
  • Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP): The investigation of choice (IOC) for diagnosing ureterocele, showing the characteristic "adder head" or "cobra head" appearance due to the dilated ureter within the bladder.

 

Cobra head or adder head appearance

Treatment

The treatment approach depends on the type of ureterocele:

  • Intravesical Ureterocele: Typically managed with an incision over the cyst wall to allow free flow of urine into the bladder, relieving the obstruction.
  • Ectopic Ureterocele: More complex, often requiring surgical excision of the ureterocele and reimplantation of the ureter into the bladder to correct the abnormal anatomy.

Associated Congenital Abnormalities
  • The most common congenital abnormality of the upper urinary tract is ureteral duplication, which can be associated with ureterocele.
  • Vesicoureteric reflux (VUR), another common congenital abnormality, may occur in conjunction with ureterocele, particularly in cases involving ureteral duplication.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man developed abdominal pain for which he was being evaluated. You notice the following in his CECT. What is the likely condition indicated by the arrow in the image?
questions.explanation:
Horseshoe kidney

Causes
  • During fetal development, the kidneys fuse at their lower poles, forming a U-shaped structure.
  • This fusion results in the inferior mesenteric artery preventing the ascent of the isthmus of the kidney to its normal position in the abdomen, leading to an abnormal location lower in the abdomen.

Clinical features
  • Mostly asymptomatic.
  • Pain: due to obstruction or renal stones.
  • Recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs).
  • Hydronephrosis.
  • Hematuria
  • Rovsing's syndrome: Hyperextension of the spine- nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain.

Investigations
  • CT Angiography (CT Angio): This is the investigation of choice for diagnosing a horseshoe kidney, as it allows for detailed visualisation of the renal anatomy, the abnormal vascular supply, and associated complications.
  • Contrast-Enhanced CT (CECT): Used when CT Angio is not available
  • Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP) - characteristic findings include:
    • Medial Orientation of Calyces: Referred to as the "Hand Joining Sign."

High Insertion of Ureters with Anterior Transposition: This creates a "Flower Vase" appearance of the ureters.

 

 

Treatment

Treatment depends on the presence and severity of symptoms:

  • Asymptomatic Patients: Typically do not require treatment but should be monitored periodically.
  • Symptomatic Patients:
    • UPJ Obstruction: Surgical intervention such as pyeloplasty
    • Kidney Stones: Management may include conservative measures like increased fluid intake, medical therapy, or surgical removal
    • UTIs: Treated with antibiotics, and preventive measures may be considered if infections are recurrent.
    • Isthmus Management: The isthmus of the horseshoe kidney should not be divided surgically as it contains functional renal tissue.
    • Pregnancy Considerations: A horseshoe kidney can lead to dystocia (difficult labour) due to the kidney's abnormal position.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a patient who visited the outpatient department (OPD) experiencing intense pain during erection and a deviated penis for the past half-year?
questions.explanation:
Peyronie’s disease

Definition

It is characterised by fibrous plaques in the tunica albuginea of the penis, causing abnormal curvature during erections.

Characteristics

Plaque Location: Typically on the dorsolateral aspect of the penis.

Curvature: Resulting from plaque contraction.

 

Causes
  • Trauma/Injury: Repeated minor trauma to the penis.
  • Genetic Factors: Possible genetic predisposition.
  • Connective Tissue Disorders: Associated with conditions like Dupuytren’s contracture.

Associated Conditions

Galezia’s Triad:

  • Dupuytren’s Contracture: Thickening and shortening of connective tissue in fingers.
  • Retroperitoneal Fibrosis: Fibrosis in the retroperitoneal space.
  • Peyronie’s Disease

Clinical Features
  • Painful Erection
  • Erectile Dysfunction
  • Penile Curvature
  • Palpable Plaques
  • Impotence & Infertility (in severe cases)

Treatment

Observation:

  • Spontaneous Resolution: Often improves without treatment.

Medical Management:

  • Oral Medications: Pentoxifylline, colchicine, vitamin E (efficacy varies).

Surgical Intervention (If Spontaneous Resolution Does Not Occur):

  • Nesbit Operation: Placement of a non-absorbable suture opposite the plaque to correct the curvature.
  • Plication Surgery: Shortens the longer side of the penis.
  • Plaque Excision and Grafting: Removes plaque and replaces it with graft material.
  • Penile Prosthesis: For severe cases.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient undergoes TURP, and after 3 days, the patient develops altered sensitiveness and drowsiness. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
TURP Syndrome

Pathophysiology

It is because fluid is absorbed intravascularly due to high volumes of hypotonic irrigation fluid used during the resection, causing dilutional hyponatremia and various neurologic symptoms.

Risk factors
  • Size of prostate > 75g
  • Duration of surgery > 90 minutes
  • Pre-existing hyponatremia
  • Renal failure

Clinical presentation
  • Confusion,
  • Agitation,
  • Nervousness,
  • Nausea,
  • Hemolysis,
  • Visual disturbances,
  • Coma and shock.

Treatment
  • Drug of choice: IV furosemide.
  • Mild to moderate cases: IV furosemide and normal saline
  • Severe or symptomatic patients: IV 3% Saline
  • Fluid restriction: Useful after initial stabilisation and correction of severe hyponatremia to prevent further fluid overload.

questions.text: What is the recommended initial investigation for genital tuberculosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Urine sample for acid-fast bacilli (AFB) culture

options.label: C
options.text: Genital swab for polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing

questions.correct_answer: C. Genital swab for polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing
questions.explanation:
Topic Genital Tuberculosis
Definition Genital tuberculosis is a form of extrapulmonary tuberculosis (TB) that affects the reproductive organs, including the fallopian tubes, uterus, ovaries, and male genital tract. It results from the spread of Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacteria to the genital organs from the primary site of infection (usually the lungs).
Causative Agent Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the bacterium responsible for tuberculosis, causes genital tuberculosis. It is transmitted through inhalation of airborne droplets containing the bacteria. The bacteria can spread from the lungs to other organs, including the genital tract, through the bloodstream or lymphatic system.
Clinical Presentation - In females: Pelvic pain, menstrual irregularities, abnormal vaginal discharge, and infertility (due to fallopian tube involvement).
  - In males: Scrotal pain, testicular swelling, and infertility (due to epididymal or vas deferens involvement).
  - Both sexes may present with constitutional symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, and night sweats.
Risk Factors - Close contact with active pulmonary tuberculosis cases.
  - Immunocompromised individuals (e.g., HIV/AIDS patients).
  - Poor living conditions and overcrowding.
Diagnosis - Genital swab or biopsy for polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing to detect Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA.
  - Histopathological examination of biopsy samples to identify granulomas (a characteristic finding in tuberculosis).
  - Imaging studies (ultrasound, hysterosalpingography, or scrotal ultrasound) to assess the extent of genital organ involvement.
Treatment Genital tuberculosis is treated with standard anti-tuberculosis drug regimens, which typically include a combination of rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol. Treatment duration may last several months to a year, depending on the severity of the disease and the response to therapy.
Complications - Infertility due to tubal obstruction or damage in females, and obstructive azoospermia (absence of sperm in semen) in males.
  - Chronic pelvic pain and scrotal discomfort.
  - Rarely, genital tuberculosis can lead to genital tract fistulas, which are abnormal connections between organs.

questions.text: Which of the following are s torage symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia ? 1. Urgency 2. Enuresis 3. Hesitancy 4. Frequency 5. Dribbling
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - 1, 2, 4

Storage Symptoms

Voiding Symptoms

Urgency: A sudden, strong urge to urinate that may be difficult to suppress.

Hesitancy: Difficulty initiating urination, often characterized by a delay in the start of the urinary stream

Enuresis: Involuntary leakage of urine during sleep.

Dribbling: Continued leakage of urine after the urinary stream has stopped.

Frequency: Need to urinate frequently, often more than 8 times a day.

Intermittency: Urine flow stops and starts during micturition.

Nocturia: Need to wake at night at least once to void.

Poor flow

Urgency Incontinence (UI): Involuntary urinary leakage, often large volume, immediately preceded by urgency.

Incomplete emptying: Sensation of bladder fullness persisting at the end of micturition.

Type of Undescended Testis

Description

Management

Prepubertal Undescended Testis (Cryptorchidism)

Testis that has not descended into the scrotum by the age of 6 months to 1 year

Observation: Spontaneous descent may occur within the first year of life; If testis remains undescended, surgical intervention is recommended

Persistent Undescended Testis

Testis that has not descended into the scrotum beyond the age of 1 year

Surgical Management: Orchidopexy (orchiopexy) - Surgical fixation of the undescended testis into the scrotum

Retractile Testis

Testis that is intermittently elevated and descends into the scrotum

Observation: No intervention is required as the testis can spontaneously descend into the scrotum; Education on testicular self-examination

Ectopic Testis

Testis located in an abnormal position outside the normal descent pathway

Surgical Management: Orchidopexy - Surgical relocation of the ectopic testis to the scrotum

Absent or Atrophic Testis

Complete absence of the testis or presence of an atrophic (non-functional) testis

No surgical intervention required; Documentation of findings and discussion with the patient and family
